definition: **Mitochondria** are <u>double-membraned organelles</u> known as the "powerhouses" of the cell. They generate <u>most of the cell's ATP via aerobic respiration</u>. Mitochondria contain their own <u>small circular DNA and ribosomes</u>, reflecting their evolutionary origin from bacteria (endosymbiosis).
tips: The inner mitochondrial membrane is highly folded into **cristae**, which increase surface area for ATP production (<u>electron transport chain and ATP synthase are located there</u>). The matrix (inner compartment) is where the **Krebs cycle** occurs.

Mitochondria are inherited almost exclusively from the mother in humans (**maternal inheritance**). This is because the egg supplies the mitochondria to the embryo. <u>Traits due to mtDNA mutations pass from mothers to all children</u>, but affected fathers do not pass them on.

Cells that require a lot of energy have many mitochondria. For example, **muscle and heart cells** are packed with mitochondria to meet energy demands. In contrast, <u>red blood cells have no mitochondria</u> (and thus produce ATP only via glycolysis).
exam_appearance: If a question mentions a <u>"double membrane organelle with its own DNA"</u> or the production of ATP, it's pointing to **mitochondria**. Common answers: "mitochondrion" or "mitochondria."

Expect questions about metabolism: e.g., "Where in the cell does the citric acid (**Krebs**) cycle occur-" -> **mitochondrial matrix**; "site of oxidative phosphorylation-" -> **inner mitochondrial membrane/cristae**.

Inheritance patterns can involve mitochondria: a classic exam scenario is a pedigree where <u>only mothers pass on a condition to all children</u> - indicating a **mitochondrial DNA disorder**. Recognize that unique maternal inheritance clue means mitochondria.
